title: Batch run
text: important note evaluating submitted scripts requires evaluation. .e. code run machine batch run initiated. encourage run code within docker container virtual machine. R code can written overwrites deletes existing files download malicious files web. extremely careful running code machine. take responsibility damage machine. single run, first define net. work assignment main page (write code sums squares number 1 5). Now, prepared assignment, can batch run. finds .R files supplied directory runs VeRitas. can now use extractFeedback extract feedback submission data frame: can also print specific feedback cat function: Furthermore possible draw overview scripts run evaluation net using analyseBatch function: Note graph terminal nodes (end nodes) contain number scripts contain, thickness edges corresponds number scripts flowed edge. obtain scripts specific terminal node, use extractScripts: Unfortunately currently possible extract scripts end nodes. working functionality. now, workaround simply add additional dummy node end, one can track. Rstudio, possible load script using rstudios api directly. example load first script obtained code line 67, use: allows efficient checking code, teacher one can, way relatively easily design new feedback rules.
code:
library(VeRitas) net <- list(start=node(has_val(ref$sol),                        goT=S2,goF=S1,                        doT="[✓] Sum is found!",                        doF="[x] Sum not found"),                          S1=node(has_val(ref$wrongsol),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doT="[?] Did you square?"),                          S2=node(did_call("sum","base"),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doF="[?] Could the sum function help?")             ) MyAssignment <- prepareAssignment(net,"../examples/01-simplest/ref1.R") batchout <- runBatch(dirname =  "../examples/01-simplest/batch-run",                      assignment = MyAssignment) #> The following files have been found: #> code1.R #> code2.R #> code3.R #>  #>  #> If you proceed - all these R files will be executed, with potentially harmful consequences to your computer. Are you certain you want to proceed? Proceeding is entirely at your own risk! #>  #> Do you wish to run all these R files? (yes/no) allfeedback <- extractFeedback(batchout) allfeedback #>                                    filename #> 1 ../examples/01-simplest/batch-run/code1.R #> 2 ../examples/01-simplest/batch-run/code2.R #> 3 ../examples/01-simplest/batch-run/code3.R #>                                                feedback #> 1              [x] Sum not found

[?] Did you square? #> 2 [✓] Sum is found!

[?] Could the sum function help? #> 3                                     [✓] Sum is found! cat(allfeedback$feedback[1]) #> [x] Sum not found #>  #> [?] Did you square? library(igraph) #> Warning: package 'igraph' was built under R version 4.4.3 analyseBatch(batchout,draw="static",layout=layout_as_tree,margin=0.3,         size=30) extractScripts(batchout, "S1") #> [1] "../examples/01-simplest/batch-run/code1.R" script <- extractScripts(batchout,"S1") rstudioapi::documentOpen(script[1])

what: Give automated feedback on submitted assignments
title: Give automated feedback on submitted assignments
text: VeRitas allows automated feedback submitted code manually designed set feedback rules. rules consist binary tests submitted code, based outcome feedback shown code sent next test.

title: Give automated feedback on submitted assignments
text: can install development version VeRitas following command (requires functioning installation devtools package):
code: devtools::install_github("koenvanbenthem/VeRitas")

title: Give automated feedback on submitted assignments
text: basic example shows solve common problem. Assume given students assignment add squares number 1 including 5 (.e. \(1^2+2^2+3^2+4^2+5^2\)). Start defining reference implementation file ref1.R, contains: reference thus holds correct solution, well common wrong solution. can now, teacher, construct decision network give feedback student code. Essentially construct list nodes, eacht takes five input arguments: check performed (can one has_val, has_each_val, did_call, has_vec) node evaluator move next condition true (goT) node evaluator move next condition false (goT) message display condition true (doT) message display condition false (doF) Variables reference solution can accessed ref$varname. One can visualise graph help igraph function drawNet function wrapper provided VeRitas: Use draw=“interactive” use igraph’s interactive plotting module. Now one can turn decision network (net) reference implementation together assignment. one file code1.R folder examples/01-simplest, contains following code: One can check running: different file, code2.R contains following code: can checked , gives: examples, check many student scripts time, please see articles website.
code: # Reference in file ref1.R # available in examples/01-simplest sol <- sum((1:5)^2) wrongsol <- sum((1:5)) library(VeRitas)  net <- list(start=node(has_val(ref$sol),                        goT=S2,goF=S1,                        doT="[✓] Sum is found!",                        doF="[x] Sum not found"),                          S1=node(has_val(ref$wrongsol),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doT="[?] Did you square?"),                          S2=node(did_call("sum","base"),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doF="[?] Could the sum function help?")             ) library(igraph) #> Warning: package 'igraph' was built under R version 4.4.3 drawNet(net,draw="static",layout=layout_as_tree,margin=0.3,         size=30) MyAssignment <- prepareAssignment(net,"examples/01-simplest/ref1.R") sum(1:5) runSingle("examples/01-simplest/code1.R",MyAssignment) #> [x] Sum not found #>  #> [?] Did you square? 1^2+2^2+3^2+4^2+5^2 runSingle("examples/01-simplest/code2.R",MyAssignment) #> [✓] Sum is found! #>  #> [?] Could the sum function help?

title: Visualise the batch run — analyseBatch
text: Draws decision net thickness edges corresponding number scripts went edge. Final nodes (END nodes) display number submissions .

title: Visualise the batch run — analyseBatch
code: analyseBatch(batchobj, draw = c("static", "interactive"), maxwidth = 5, ...)

title: Visualise the batch run — analyseBatch
text: batchobj object generated batchRun draw character indicating whether one wants make static interactive igraph plot maxwidth maximum width edges ... Additional arguments passed igraphs plotting functions.

what: Check whether a function was called by code — did_call
title: Check whether a function was called by code — did_call
text: Function checking whether submitted code calls specific function. tracks functions called package attached (.e. can track plot, base::plot). track functions load datasets (.e. read.csv).

title: Check whether a function was called by code — did_call
code: did_call(fun, pkg, obj, args = NULL, tol = sqrt(.Machine$double.eps))

title: Check whether a function was called by code — did_call
text: fun function one wants track, provided character pkg packages function comes , provided character obj object passed evaluator (need supplied user) args list single value arguments need passed tracked function, did_call return true tol tolerance arguments

title: Check whether a function was called by code — did_call
text: true false

title: Draw a decision network — drawNet
text: Draws decision network visual inspection

title: Draw a decision network — drawNet
code: drawNet(net, draw = c("none", "interactive", "static"), ...)

title: Draw a decision network — drawNet
text: net list nodes (see node). node called END. One node called start (first) draw Whether static interactive plot (letter nodes can dragged around) ... Additional parameters passed igraph plotting functions

what: Check whether each value in a vector is produced by code — has_each_val

text: Function checking whether submitted code produces value certain vector. search care values found. Also, account multiples (.e. distinguish code produces certain value one produces twice)

code: has_each_val(   values,   obj,   text = FALSE,   tol = sqrt(.Machine$double.eps),   absval = FALSE )

title: Check whether each value in a vector is produced by code — has_each_val
text: obj object passed evaluator (need supplied user) text boolean indicates whether also code scanned values (just output/generated variables) tol tolerance absval Whether absolute values matched. true, values obj vec first turned absolute values checking. value vector values one looking

title: Create a node — node
text: Allows user define new node.

title: Create a node — node
code: node(cond, goT = "END", goF = "END", doT = "", doF = "")

title: Create a node — node
text: cond condition defined  has_vec, has_val, has_each_val did_call. goT node evaluator moves condition cond true. goF node evaluator moves condition cond false. doT message display condition cond true. doF message display condition cond true.

title: Create a node — node
code: node(did_call('plot','base'),goT=S2,goF="END",doT="message displayed if true",doF="message displayed if false") #>                  condition goT goF                       doT #> 1 did_call("plot", "base")  S2 END message displayed if true #>                          doF #> 1 message displayed if false

title: Assignment setup — prepareAssignment
text: Uses assessment net (named list nodes) reference file prepare assignment.

title: Assignment setup — prepareAssignment
code: prepareAssignment(net, referencefile)

title: Assignment setup — prepareAssignment
text: net named list nodes (see node) describes checks performed feedback yield. first node named start, final nodes named END. nodes start words name. referencefile R script contains reference solution. checks nodes use values reference solution.

title: Assignment setup — prepareAssignment
text: Returns initialized assignment, essence list contains net, functions tracked, output reference file.

title: Function for running a set of scripts Use with caution! If you run this script, all submitted R scripts will be executed automatically. Be sure that you trust these scripts - they could severely harm your computer. — runBatch
text: dirname Character, directory contains scripts analysing. assignment assignment, prepared prepareAssignment. pattern pattern R scripts adhere . default files ending .R found. rec Whether find files recursively, .e. subdirectories . overridewarnings Whether show warning running function.

title: Function for running a set of scripts Use with caution! If you run this script, all submitted R scripts will be executed automatically. Be sure that you trust these scripts - they could severely harm your computer. — runBatch

title: Evaluate a single script. — runSingle
code: # example code library(VeRitas) net <- list(start=node(has_val(ref$sol),                        goT=S2,goF=S1,                        doT="[✓] Sum is found!",                        doF="[x] Sum not found"),              S1=node(has_val(ref$wrongsol),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doT="[?] Did you square?"),               S2=node(did_call("sum","base"),                     goT=END,goF=END,                     doF="[?] Could the sum function help?") ) MyAssignment <- prepareAssignment(net,"../../examples/01-simplest/ref1.R") runSingle("../../examples/01-simplest/code2.R",MyAssignment) #> [✓] Sum is found! #>  #> [?] Could the sum function help? #>
